captions.text:
Good morning John! Last week I said some really
mean things about books, and books actually

saw the video and left a really nasty comment.
As an apology, let's talk about the best entertainment
investments you can make.

There are lots of different kinds and levels
of quality of entertainments, and also different

amounts of money you can spend being entertained.
Worst investments are usually live events.

Of course hopefully that means that the quality
of the entertainment is higher.

The Super Bowl, for example, this year a very
bad game, not interesting. People pay upwards

of two thousand dollars to get a ticket to
the Super Bowl for less than four hours of

entertainment! That's, that's more than five
hundred dollars per hour of entertainment.
That's about as bad as you can get.

Vidcon- also a live event but it goes for
a long time. It's two days, and like, all

the way around almost, it's like 10 a.m. to
2 a.m. If you're spending all of that time

being entertained, and I hope you are, and
you pay the current 150 dollar per ticket

price then it's five dollars per hour of entertainment.
That's pretty good!

It's the same as if you pay ten dollars for
a two-hour movie, as long as you don't buy

the tremendously overpriced snack foods. Also
as long as you're not seeing a 3D movie. Or

in the special theater, or it's a special
edition movie, or you live in a place where
it's more than $10.

Video games are one of the most popular forms
of entertainment these days, usually debuting

about $60 and taking about 40 hours to beat.
Not bad at all! Comics, though I love them

and they're beautiful little pieces of art,
and sometimes they do hold on to their value-

bad investment. Takes like 20 minutes to read
and is 3 bucks, so that's bad.

Board games and card games are generally a
fantastic investment, so long as you play

them. So once you accept the cost, every time
you play it you are getting a better value.
Now let's bring it on back to my friend books.

The Fault in Our Stars is currently on sale
at Amazon for seven dollars. This book, it

took me about 20 hours to finish. I'm admittedly
a slow reader so let's shave some time off

of that. 46 cents per hour! This- now we're
talking! At the same time though all of our

other entertainments are much more expensive
than this, so really it's probably OK to pay

full price for that book. I'm only paying
like 67 cents more per hour!

Really, to me, that's the amount of money
I am paying to the local bookstore when I

buy it there rather than on Amazon. 67 cents
per hour of enjoyment that I am trading in

exchange for a place where I can go and look
at books! Nice people who will help me find
things! shelves and shelves of opportunity!

Of course, we haven't even mentioned America's
main source of

entertainment, that being television. Average
cost of cable television package is a hundred

and twenty eight dollars per month. Now that's
a lot of money, but since the average American

spends -and I cannot believe this is true-
34 hours per week watching television, it's
actually a really good deal!

However, no one's pretending that the amount
of time you' spend watching TV is comparable

to the amount of time you spend enjoying Vidcon.
Hopefully, 20 hours of Vidcon is more than

10 times more entertaining than 20 hours of
television. And yeah, I think 20 hours of

reading a book is probably more enriching
than 20 hours of playing Grand Theft Auto.

It doesn't seem like there's a huge amount
of correlation between the amount of dollars

delivered and the amount of value delivered,
which is why I guess it makes sense that a
lot of the best things in life are free.

(singing Money (That's What I Want) by The
Beatles)

But you can keep 'em for the birds and bees
I want money

That's what I want
That's what I want
That's what I want
(speaking)
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

comments.text:
This is an interesting way to look at it. I mean I have thought that way 
about clothes before. That's probably because I worked in retail selling 
them; so I'd say something about that in order to ease the customers mind 
while they are paying for it. 
"If you wear it twenty times then it only cost a dollar."
I think it was something you could wear that many times--easy.

Anyway, I myself have a hard time spending money on myself when it comes to 
something fun. Sure I can drop cash on nearly anything experience related; 
but when it comes to video games, artist programs and other such 
things--it's just hard. I guess because I know I need experiences to grow 
and learn, which is important to me, but I don't technically NEED the other 
things if I can get something similar for free. At the same time I am 
actually missing out on certain experiences because of that.

So really...I need to think about the cost of not buying an item and 
whether I'm losing something important because I just don't want to shell 
out the money. It's obvious that the cost of a Superbowl ticket would mean 
nothing to me because the experience would be priceless--especially if the 
team I root for was playing. It is also more about who I am with. Then why 
is it so hard for me to buy a video game that was marked down to ten 
dollars? Just because it's not an event doesn't give it less value. I've 
played a type of game before; but that one would give me a different 
experience just as much as a trip to a country that I haven't been to 
before.
Maybe it is related to how much weight I actually put on a particular 
experience...I'm going to stop typing out my thoughts now. haha﻿

comments.author: Connor Milligan

comments.text:
While for the most part I won't disagree that, ideally, a book should be 
more enriching than a video game, there are plenty of exceptions that make 
the statement less true. Video games have become an excellent medium for 
not only storytelling, but also for expressing ideas, morals, (in)equality 
struggles, differences in culture, I'm sure we could go on. The best two 
examples I can think of instantly are Mass Effect and Assassin's Creed. 
In Mass Effect, if you do, as you say, explore all the content, you will 
learn about many cultures and their morals that, while fictional, may or 
may not have real world origins or at the very least real world 
applications. Also the ongoing decisions, many of which put you in 
situations where you must decide between the needs of the many, few, or 
self.
Assassin's Creed is one of my favorite franchises and one of the main 
reasons is because, while you start off with a very clear distinction of 
good guys vs bad guys, as your character converses with their dying 
enemies, you learn that many of them have noble intentions and goals; some 
of them even just happen to be on the wrong side and just don't realize it. 
While this doesn't tend to be true for the higher ranking Templars, the 
lines between right and wrong still quite often become extremely blurred.
On the other side of this topic are books, and, again, while I agree that 
most books SHOULD be more enriching, as another commenter pointed out, 
there are a LOT of bad books out there these days. That's not to say there 
aren't bad games, but it is easier and cheaper to write, publish, and 
distribute a book than most other entertainment mediums; bad content will 
filter through by volume alone. Admittedly I'm not a huge reader so I don't 
have any readily available examples, but I'm willing to risk YouTube 
comment flak on the assumption that plenty of people would not disagree.﻿

comments.author: Ch1Frequency

comments.text:
Two things to note.

One, the publishing of books has pretty much always been that way, with way 
more crap than good stuff. The thing is, if you're reading anything 
actually prominent for its time period, it would have sifted through all of 
the crap and climbed into the upper echelons of the best books available 
just to be worth noticing for literary purposes in the modern era. You 
don't read crap from the 1800's, the crap is sitting unread in dusty 
shelves while you're reading some of the best stuff able to be produced 
during that period.

Two, it's really hard to moderate book quality, because everybody has 
different standards of quality. Which is, in my own humble opinion, not a 
bad thing in the slightest. Books like Twilight receive a mixture of large 
popularity and large hatred because (
*coughpeoplehavenoliterarystandardscough*) different people have different 
yet valid opinions on the book's quality. Some people see it as badly 
written, shallow, and meaningless, while others consider it a masterful 
example of how primal and vain the thing teenagers refer to as "love" truly 
is. There are no objective standards of quality, at least not when it comes 
to how well a book was written, and to be honest, even as somebody who 
strongly rejects the idea that falling into certain habits based on their 
popularity is a good idea, it is also very difficult for me to agree with 
somebody who says that an incredibly popular book is truly a bad book. The 
purpose of a book is to inform, entertain, or influence in a certain 
direction an audience. If you've done any of the above to a large degree to 
a large number of people, then how can that book really be considered a 
failure? That vagueness as to what qualities contribute to a book being 
good, and the fact that even clearly defined rules pertaining what one 
person may consider good don't provide a whole lot of help telling what 
somebody else will think is good, combined with the necessity to experiment 
with things that might not and often don't work in order to avoid writing a 
book somebody else basically already wrote, result in a system where the 
vast majority of books will, by necessity, be considered totally awful by a 
good portion of the people who read them. This doesn't mean they're 
necessarily bad books, nor does it mean they're necessarily good books, nor 
do distinctions between bad and good even exist beyond a certain point in 
literature. There are objectively bad qualities in a book, but most of that 
has to do with the writers making distinct errors in literary theory and 
have nothing to do with the intelligence or creative writing capacity of 
the author.

So I say, keep releasing books I hate. I know a few gems will appear in the 
tidal wave of crap.
comments.author: HeliosKitty

comments.text:
I have friends that are not interested even in books, but I still have fun 
with them. Probably because I like to see that there is different kinds of 
minds. Like, I've known tons of people who don't like reading stories, but 
are greatly interested in science, even if they don't know anything about 
it, and when you talk to them, you see the light of curiosity in their 
eyes. For me that's more important than what a person reads or if he reads 
at all. My friends might not be the people with the deepest minds, but 
neither we are as deep as we think. The world is not inhabited by mindless 
drones who just randomly survives the earth. Each person has their own 
philosophy, and goals and tastes of pizza. I've known smarter hobos who 
hadn't read a book than some of the PhDs in my University.
comments.author: Ch1Frequency

comments.text:
Oh no, not at all.   My past (and admittedly, limited) experience with 
people who have narrow, specific views on what constitutes a "good" 
anything (book, movie, band, game, hobby, etc) I have personally found to 
be somewhat shallow and narrow-minded - I know that this is not the case 
for ALL people who like specific things, merely what I have come across in 
my own experience, which makes me hesitant to befriend new people if I see 
that facet of their personality before I see other awesome things about 
them.  (Hell, I don't care what you read, the fact that you DO gives you 10 
cool points in my eyes)

I think it's fantastic to have preferences (I do, I'm a sci-fi and fantasy 
reader as a general rule), but the type of people I have had dealings with 
who have limited preferences or are not open to trying new 
books/bands/games etc I also found to be limited and hesitant to try new 
things in general - be it trying a new cuisine, or listening to other 
people's points of view when talking or even going out to a new place. 

So.. yeah. Like I said, just me and my own experiences, admittedly I'm not 
a social butterfly while I KNOW not everyone is like that, it's what I've 
come across and while I value everyone's right to choose what they like and 
to stick to it, I value my own right to spend my spare time with people who 
are willing to explore new things with me and introduce me to new awesome 
stuff.
comments.author: Stacey Parkes

comments.author: Nick Brocious

comments.text:
What a strange way to look at reading a book.  In my opinion the time it 
takes to read a book is part of the cost not part of the value.  If I could 
read a book in 20 hours or if I could read the same book in 10 hours I 
would be much better off if I chose to read it in 10 hours regardless of 
whether I'm reading it purely for pleasure or to lean something, either way 
I have an extra ten hours I could use to read something else.﻿
comments.author: Joe Lima

comments.text:
No, that's not quite what I was saying.  The enjoyment of a book, as you 
mention, tends to lay in the reflection upon what you've read rather than 
the fact that you are reading.  If you just wanted to read then you could 
read the phone book or youtube comments.

Thus the enjoyment of a book, in my opinion, has nothing to do with the 
amount of time it takes to read it (I still maintain that with equal or 
better retention I would be much happier reading a book in a minute as 
opposed to a day).  If you learn a lifelong lesson or fondly recall a book 
for the rest of your life, or it introduces you to entire new concepts, the 
value is obviously incredible but has nothing to do with how many pages 
long it was or the amount of time you spent on each paragraph.

Compare this to a book which you have mostly forgotten that you've read a 
month or two later.  You essentially got no value out of reading it and 
your time was wasted, you could have spent it doing any number of other 
things including reading a better book.  Or if you read it extremely 
quickly then at least you wasted relatively little time.
comments.author: Joe Lima

comments.text:
+Joe Lima I think you're looking at the time perspective wrong. Yes, if you 
read more quickly (but not to the point where you miss things or don't 
remember what you just read, as you mentioned), you can then access more 
content within the same amount of time, and as long as all that content is 
good, the amount of enjoyment per unit of time will generally increase 
assuming you draw pleasure strictly from the reading of content (rather 
than from things that might slow you down, like taking a few minutes to 
reflect on the meaning of what you read). However, the idea here is less 
that reading the same book more slowly gives you more enjoyment, but rather 
that reading a longer book with a proportionally greater amount of 
enjoyable content for the same price as a shorter book is a better 
investment. Keep in mind, a book isn't like one big packet of one thing, 
it's a mesh of things and you receive new (hopefully enjoyable) content 
from paragraph to paragraph if not sentence to sentence. It's much like 
your example of enjoying extra content in a game; if you receive the same 
enjoyment per minute reading one book as another book, and this enjoyment 
does not increase or diminish substantially over the course of the book, 
and both cost, say, $30, then would you rather read the one that's 450 
pages long, or the one that's 800 pages long? You're getting more content 
and longer-lasting enjoyment for your dollar out of the second book. 
Granted, some books are better left shorter, so I might consider both books 
equally good after the fact; but while I'm reading them, I get to enjoy one 
longer than I get to enjoy the other, and the enjoyment is the same 
(preferably high) per minute no matter which book I read, so I'd rather 
read for longer.

If that makes any sense. I'm just weird and love reading, so keep that in 
mind.
comments.author: HeliosKitty

comments.text:
While all that can be true to some people, others, like myself, enjoy the 
act of reading just as much as the content of the book. It's my time to sit 
back and relax.So I do think I could get the same amount of enjoyment if I 
went through books faster, I would not get more. I even might lose some 
enjoyment, because I would not be immersed in the world the book creates 
for as long. (Which is the best part of any fiction at least.) I guess that 
means I have a problem with the thought of being able to read at a fast 
pace and being able to have the same retention. While I would still know 
all of the information, the time allotment for imagination is taken away.
Also, if one were to read through books at an alarming rate, then the cost 
of reading would skyrocket. It would no longer be feasible to buy books 
because you'd have to buy so many more to fulfill the same amount of time.
comments.author: Alan Gott

comments.text:
The point is how much enjoyment do you get out of it.  Presumably if the 
game is taking a long time it is because you are enjoying the extra 
content.  If there is no extra content and it is just taking a long time 
because you do everything very slowly then yes, if you could do it more 
quickly you would probably get more enjoyment and less frustration out of 
it.   A book will contain the same words regardless of how quickly you read 
it.  I guess if you have too much free time on your hands and can't manage 
to fill it so you like to read slowly that's fine but it seems to me there 
are so many hundreds and thousands of books that reading quickly (while 
maintaining or improving retention) will only increase your enjoyment.
comments.author: Joe Lima

comments.text:
The same could be said for everything else then. Wouldn't it be much better 
to play through a video game in 10 hours instead of 40? Then you could play 
so many more games!

comments.author: Goose Perception

comments.text:
60 dollars for a video game that then takes 40 hours to beat? That's 
probably a JRPG. Lots of western games take a lot less to beat. On the 
other hand, multiplayer seems to be more of a thing in western games. No 
one ever buys Battlefield for the single player campaign and its storyline. 
In fact, only the recent iterations even have a single player campaign with 
a storyline. 

And then there are things like DotA2. I've had almost 700 hours of fun so 
far and it only cost me 3.60 euros, and only because I felt like spending 
that money on DotA2. 

Also, 130 dollars for a TV subscription? WTF? I think we pay 40 or 60 
euros, something like that, and that includes the most popular channels, 
optic fibre internet and telephony. ﻿
